properties.ariaLabel: upgrading from v73 to v80 permalink

children.value: The key goals of luma.gl v8.0 were to simplify the core architecture and significantly improve performance. The number of modules has been reduced from 14 to 9, and they are now structured around layers of abstraction (high-level to low-level) to clarify the relationship between them. Unfinished and rarely-used components have been removed, reducing the complexity of the API and leading to significant performance gains (see
The module structure has been significantly changed for v8.0 with the intention of clarifying the purpose of each module and the relationships between them.
Tools for manipulating and composing shader text
Creation, tooling and polyfilling for the WebGL context
Single module re-exporting key parts of engine, webgl, gltools, shadertools
core/model, core/animation-loop, core/resource-management, addons/animation, core/geometry, core/transform
Debug tooling for the other modules
Test tooling for the other modules

option is removed. This change ensures that all data sources (Image, ImageBitmap, typed array) are treated consistently. As a result, textures created from Image objects and URL strings are now y-flipped from the v7.3 default. To get the old behavior, specify the
will no longer attempt to create a headlessgl context under node.js. One can either create headless context externally and use
to prepare it for use with luma.gl or use
has been removed. Modules can be imported and used directly where necessary.
been removed. Use the shader module
The following are no longer exported by @luma.gl/core, but can still be imported from the modules indicated:
Query, VertexArrayObject, VertexArray, UniformBufferLayout, Shader, VertexShader, FragmentShader, clearBuffer, clearBuffer, copyToDataUrl, copyToImage, blit, setPathPrefix, loadFile, loadImage
combineInjects, lights, getQualifierDetails, getPassthroughFS, typeToChannelSuffix, typeToChannelCount, convertToVec4
Functions are no longer accepted as uniform values to the
class. The same effect can be achieved by updating the uniform values each frame prior to drawing.
can be used as a substitute for
have been removed from @luma.gl/core. These were either empty classes or simple data objects and so can be replaced by plain JavaScript objects in most cases.
has been removed and superseded by
no longer takes overrides as an argument. The calling function can manually override values as needed.
@luma.gl/main has been removed. Use individual modules instead.
Timeline and Keyframes have been moved from @luma.gl/addons to @luma.gl/engine.

properties.ariaLabel: upgrading from v6x to v70 permalink

children.value: luma.gl v7.0 represents a major overhaul of the API. The majority of changes are in areas that are only infrequently used by applications, and the intention is that most applications should only require very light porting.
Extensive loading functionality is now provided by a new companion framework
and because of this, most of the limited legacy luma.gl loading functions have been removed.
For the most common case (loading of images for use with textures), loading functions are no longer needed as the
constructor now accepts url strings and
objects (this is the new Async Textures function).
This experimental class has been moved to deck.gl and is now an internal class. Attribute accessor API improvements in luma.gl v7 should cover any issue.
class has been removed as its utility was limited and it added complexity to the library. It may be added back in the future if a clear use case arises.
class has been removed as its utility was limited and the status of support was unclear due to limited testing. It may be added back in the future if a clear use case arises.
class has been removed as its utility was limited. It may be added back in the future if a clear use case arises. If required, syncing can be done directly through the

children.value: Framebuffer and Texture: Copy and Blit methods
classes are no longer supported, instead use the corresponding new global methods:
Parameters have also changed in some cases, see separate section.

properties.ariaLabel: debug functionality moved to separate npm module permalink

children.value: Debug functionality moved to separate npm module
To reduce bundle size and increase separation of concerns, debug functionality is now more cleanly separated from the core library and needs to be imported from a separate npm module:
To upgrade, install the new module
. This ensures that applications that do not need scenegraph support do not need to include scenegraph related code. Use the new
Redraw flag handling has been removed:
method is provided, indicating that redraws are required every frame.
class has been simplified and is now a conceptually "immutable" class that holds typed arrays and accessor metatadata describing attributes for a geometry.
To maximize rendering performance, the default framebuffer is no longer preserved between frames.
The most common use case for preserving the draw buffer is capturing canvas contents into an image via
. This can now be done via
that resolves to the canvas data URL:
More generally, moving code that depends on canvas contents to the end of
, after all draw operations, will ensure that canvas contents are available.
Prior behaviour can re-enabled using the
may result in a performance drop on some platforms.
to retrieve timer results in milliseconds.
To improve performance and simplify the library, support for tracking
instances with promises has changed: The
now provides a simple, optional promise-based API.

properties.ariaLabel: copy and blit parameter unification permalink

children.value: Names of certain parameters to these methods have been unified in an effort to reduce confusion and use the same conventions across all functions implementing image read-back, copy or blit.
This table lists parameter mapping between old and new function.
Geometry scenegraph models have been deprecated. Simply create a

properties.ariaLabel: upgrading from v53 to v60 permalink

children.value: luma.gl v6.0 underwent a major API cleanup, resulting in a smaller, easier-to-learn API and smaller application bundles. While there are many smaller changes, the impact on most applications should be limited:
Most removed functions were in practice rarely used by applications, and the impact on typical luma.gl applications should be limited.
A number of API changes are related to moving attribute management from
, however for higher level applications that work with the
directly, there should not be much impact.
The biggest change for many apps will probably be that the static
symbol (that contains all WebGL 2 constants) must now be separately imported GL from 'luma.gl/constants'.

properties.ariaLabel: experimental exports new naming convention permalink

children.value: Experimental exports are now prefixed with underscore (_). The
This change will enable tree-shaking bundlers to remove unused experimental exports, resulting in smaller final application bundles.
Math functions were moved from luma.gl to the separate math.gl module in v4.1. As of v6.0, they are no longer forwarded by luma.gl and now need to be imported directly from math.gl:
luma.gl v6.0 removes a number of previously deprecated symbols. luma.gl will now issue an error rather than a warning if the old usage is detecated.

children.value: is no longer required for luma.gl to load headless gl and the usage has been deprecated. You can now simply remove any such import statements from your code.

are automatically installed when luma.gl is installed, but are not actually bundled into the application unless explicitly imported. This avoids impacting the size of production bundles built on luma.gl that typically do not need debug support.
To use debug support, first import the debug tools, then call

properties.ariaLabel: upgrading from v4 to v5 permalink

children.value: Please read this documentation before upgrading your luma.gl dependency from v4 to v5. In v5 a number of previously deprecated features have been removed and a number of additional deprecations have been made at the same time.

Before upgrading to v5, it is highly recommended to run your application using latest v4 release, and check the console for any deprecated warnings, if there are any replace deprecated API with newer API as listed below.
constructor expects a gl context as the first argument.
Following style construction was deprecated in v4 and is now removed in v5.
is used as a an argument in
method. It is now deprecated in v5, but still supported with a warning message and will be removed in next major version update. It is recommended to use
class construction with inline attributes was deprecated in v4 and now removed in v5.
All attributes should be grouped inside
Following features were deprecated in v3 and v4 are now removed in v5.

properties.ariaLabel: upgrading from v3 to v4 permalink

children.value:
luma.gl v4 is a major release with API changes. Please read this documentation before upgrading your luma.gl's dependency from v3 to v4.
In addition, a number of previously deprecated features have been removed and a number of additional deprecations have been made at the same time in this version.
Some previously deprecated classes and functions have been removed in luma.gl v4 and applications must be updated with the new classes and functions if they are still using these.

Some classes and functions have been deprecated in luma.gl v4. They will continue to function in v4, but a warning in the console will be generated. These functions are expected to be removed in a future major versions of luma.gl.
constructor now expects a gl context as the first argument.

the gl context used to be extracted from the supplied program or provided along side with other options, but in luma.gl v4, it is expected as a separate argument to the constructor. This change is because luma.gl v4 emphasizes sharing shaders rather than programs (often indirectly via shader caching / shader assembly), it is less common that a gl context is available.

properties.ariaLabel: upgrading from v2 to v3 permalink

children.value: V3 was a fairly minor release, a number of deprecations were made.
